name: Can a Machine Think Like a Chef?
description:
Can we teach a machine to understand food?

Join Ganesh Bagler as he explains how the rapid growth of food-related data and advances in artificial intelligence are transforming how we understand the science of gastronomy. Learn about the emerging discipline of computational gastronomy, a field that applies data science and AI to investigate culinary patterns, nutritional structures, and flavour principles. Explore how making food computable is allowing us to decode long-standing culinary mysteries, uncover the links between diet and health, and design innovative food solutions. Discover the implications this holds for public health, personalised nutrition, and sustainable food systems.

name: Legal Enclosures and Coastal Commons
description:
How does the law affect coastal food systems? 

Join Kanchi Kohli for a workshop that will bring to life the different ways in which the shape, size and social relation of coastal commons can be transformed through environmental laws. Learn what this relationship means for coastal ecology, livelihoods and food systems.

The participants will be tasked to engage with the structural character of a few legal frameworks and work through how they can be altered to address specific challenges and potentially create solutions to better safeguard our coasts.

name: Eat, Read, Think
description:
Eat, Read, Think is a reading circle run by Science Gallery Bengaluru, bringing together curious minds to explore ideas through literature and conversation. Readings will be themed around the current exhibition season, CALORIE, exploring humanity's fraught and intimate relationship with food through readings inspired by the many exhibits present throughout the gallery. Eat, Read, Think welcomes young people from all walks of life to gather for conversations that connect science, culture and society.

For the third session of the reading circle, we will be reading through a firsthand account of the Bengal Famine, published in 1946. "Famine is like this" by John Frederick Muehl.

name:
Educator Workshop: 
Interdisciplinary Thinking In Practice
description:
Click here to [register]! 

Learning is often presented as distinct, neatly defined subjects.
Interdisciplinary thinking integrates them, opening up a word that is complex, interconnected, and full of surprises!

The Educator Workshop is a full-day immersive workshop for educators from across the city, to explore new ideas, think across disciplines, and reimagine learning together. Because the future of education is becoming increasingly interdisciplinary.

What to expect?
> Experience our exhibition-season CALORIE, where ideas from science, art, design, and society intersect.
> Unpack interdisciplinarity through hands-on activities and reflective discussions.
> Explore NCERT topics through a fresh lens.
> Collaborate in small groups to design practical ideas for sparking interdisciplinarity in the classroom. 
> Present your insights in a lively pitching session.

Who is this for?
Educators and teachers across subjects (Classes 7–12) who value curiosity, inquiry, and exploring ideas across disciplines.


Come, be a learner for a day.
Connect with fellow educators.
Return inspired—with practical tools and renewed energy for teaching.

name: CA-LORE-EE: What’s your story?
description:
Something grown, something bought, something eaten, something caught.

Moras, azúcar, sakkare, cheeni, qand, misri… one ingredient, many tales. But we’re not just talking sugar here! It’s about how words, objects, and habits collect stories over time. Could these stories be created through what we grow, buy, cook, share, remember, and even forget? 

Come find out on a walk with Thejaswini and Sai as they poke, prod, and nibble at the exhibits to uncover what’s been hiding in plain sight. So, we’re spilling some tea. What about you?

name: My Radio My Life: Film Screening and Discussion
description:
My Radio My Life” is a distinctive documentary that nostalgically revisits the golden era of radio and its profound influence on people’s lives. The film journeys through a vintage radio museum curated by a passionate restorer in Bengaluru, revisits the historic 1969 Apollo 11 Moon landing commentary from the Voice of America (Tamil Service), and highlights the crucial role of Ham Radio during disasters such as tsunamis. It also traces how a childhood fascination with radio inspired individuals to become popular announcers, celebrates beloved programmes like Binaca Geetmala and cricket commentary, and follows the determined efforts of a retired librarian repairing his cherished radio.

The film further showcases the exciting revival of School Radio, where students are reimagining the magic of radio in new and innovative ways.

“My Radio My Life” has been screened at over 80 film festivals across 36 countries, earning multiple awards and nominations for its heartfelt storytelling and cultural significance.

Join filmmaker Makarand Waikar and Creative Producer Simantinee Bhagwat as they explore the film’s concept, creative journey, and the enduring themes it explores.

name: Making Food Computable
description:
Can cuisines, recipes, flavours and nutrition all be translated into data?

Join Ganesh Bagler for a masterclass on Computational Gastronomy. Learn the methodology, data and algorithms behind making food computable. explore the process of converting culinary knowledge into structured representations, analyze real examples from global cuisines, experimenting with outputs like generating flavour pairings and creating nutrition models.

Ganesh Bagler will demonstrate how databases, machine learning models, and multimodal analytics can be built, queried, and extended for research or innovation. Come and learn how to think computationally about food and discover the real life applications of this emerging science.
